body: @StepOfDeath Honestly I don't really think this needed to be said. Armchair psychology for a doujin author seems kinda dumb imo. In the end the only person who even has a chance of knowing why they do what they do is the author themselves, and even then knowing yourself well enough to make informed psychological analysis is exceedingly rare. Chalking up something you don't agree or vibe with to some type of trauma is pretty disingenuous.

I'm not gonna be a hypocrite and speak ill of this author's work, which I really enjoy, but I must say I get some serious "Akai Mato" vibes from them. As in, it feels like the author was either dumped/cheated on or had an absent father figure in their life, because it honestly feels like there's some kind of resentment or anger towards men between the lines. Literally every single one of their titles portray men as spineless and submissive to the point where they're always willing to discard their dignity, life savings and even their humanity for the sake of getting bullied. Hell, in this manga the girls even control what kind of underwear the guy wears. You might argue that they're just exploring a fetish, but when there's hardly any distiction from any of their many stories, it feels like the author strongly believes that men in general are actually like this: easy to break and control. Like I said I do enjoy their work, but I do cringe a little sometimes.

@Iexpectedbetter as a long time practitioner of S and M with various partners, including my now wife, I can assure you that trust, consent, and safety are viewed as essential aspects by the majority of the practicing community. That of course doesn't mean there aren't exceptions, and in pure fantasy form like this it doesn't need to follow how you would enjoy it being done to you in reality.
